statement.text: The popliteal artery bifurcates into the anterior tibial artery and tibioperoneal trunk, which subsequently divides into the posterior tibial and peroneal arteries, providing three potential targets for below-knee revascularization.

explanation.intuition: Below the knee, the blood supply splits like a tree branch: first one branch goes to the front of the leg (anterior tibial), then the remaining trunk splits into two more branches for the back (posterior tibial) and side (peroneal) of the leg.
explanation.key_insight: The angiosome concept links each tibial artery to specific foot territories: anterior tibial→dorsalis pedis→dorsum of foot, posterior tibial→plantar arteries→sole, peroneal→lateral ankle/heel. Direct revascularization to the wound's angiosome improves healing.
explanation.technical_details: Popliteal bifurcation: at lower border of popliteus muscle. Anterior tibial: passes through interosseous membrane to anterior compartment, becomes dorsalis pedis. Tibioperoneal trunk: 2-4cm long, divides into posterior tibial and peroneal. Posterior tibial: deep to soleus, passes behind medial malleolus, becomes plantar arteries. Peroneal: courses along fibula, terminates as calcaneal branches. Variant: high takeoff of anterior tibial (5-10%).

anatomic_features.anterior_tibial: Anterior compartment → dorsalis pedis → dorsum of foot
anatomic_features.tibioperoneal_trunk: 2-4cm length, divides into posterior tibial and peroneal
anatomic_features.posterior_tibial: Behind medial malleolus → plantar arteries → sole of foot
anatomic_features.peroneal: Along fibula → calcaneal branches → lateral ankle/heel

clinical_pearls: Angiosome-directed revascularization may improve wound healing
Posterior tibial supplies the sole - critical for weight-bearing
Peroneal is often last to occlude in diabetes
